raw_text: KRISP (Kate and Mooney, 2006) is a semantic parser learning system which uses word subsequence kernel based SVM (Cristianini and Shawe-Taylor, 2000) classifiers and was shown to be robust to noise compared to other semantic parser learners
clean_text: KRISP (Kate and Mooney, 2006) is a semantic parser learning system which uses word subsequence kernel based SVM (Cristianini and Shawe-Taylor, 2000) classifiers and was shown to be robust to noise compared to other semantic parser learners.

raw_text: For details please refer to (Kate and Mooney, 2006) .The key operation in KRISP is to find the similarity between any two substrings of two natural language sentences
clean_text: For details please refer to (Kate and Mooney, 2006).

raw_text: Word subsequence kernel was employed in (Kate and Mooney, 2006) to compute the similarity between two substrings
clean_text: Word subsequence kernel was employed in (Kate and Mooney, 2006) to compute the similarity between two substrings.

citing_paper_authors: Rohit J., Kate | Raymond J., Mooney
raw_text: We note that this use of multiple classifiers to determine the most probable parse is similar to the method used in the KRISP semantic parser (Kate and Mooney, 2006)
clean_text: We note that this use of multiple classifiers to determine the most probable parse is similar to the method used in the KRISP semantic parser (Kate and Mooney, 2006).

raw_text: We introduce grammar transformation operators and meaning representation macros to transform an MRG.We describe how these are applied in an error driven manner using the base semantic parsing learning algorithm presented in (Kate and Mooney, 2006) resulting in a better learned semantic parser. Our approach, however, is general enough to improve any semantic parser learning system which uses productions of the MRG
clean_text: We describe how these are applied in an error driven manner using the base semantic parsing learning algorithm presented in (Kate and Mooney, 2006) resulting in a better learned semantic parser.

raw_text: SystemWe very briefly describe the semantic parser learning system, KRISP (Kate and Mooney, 2006), which we will use as a base system for transforming MRGs, we however note that the MRG transformation methods presented in this paper are general enough to work with any system which learns semantic parser using MRGs
clean_text: We very briefly describe the semantic parser learning system, KRISP (Kate and Mooney, 2006), which we will use as a base system for transforming MRGs, we however note that the MRG transformation methods presented in this paper are general enough to work with any system which learns semantic parser using MRGs.

raw_text: KRISP (Kate and Mooney, 2006) is a discriminative approach where meaning representation structures are constructed from the natural language strings hierarchically
clean_text: KRISP (Kate and Mooney, 2006) is a discriminative approach where meaning representation structures are constructed from the natural language strings hierarchically.

citing_paper_authors: Bevan K., Jones | Mark, Johnson | Sharon, Goldwater
raw_text: The tree transducer, on the other hand, naturally captures the same probabilistic dependencies while maintaining the separation between MR and NL, and further al lows us to build upon a larger body of theory.KRISP (Kate and Mooney, 2006) uses string classifiers to label substrings of the NL with entities from the MR. To focus search, they impose an ordering constraint based on the structure of the MR tree, which they relax by allowing the re-ordering of sibling nodes and devise a procedure for recovering the MR from the permuted tree
clean_text: KRISP (Kate and Mooney, 2006) uses string classifiers to label substrings of the NL with entities from the MR.

raw_text: The remaining refined landmarks plans are then treated as supervised training data for a semantic-parser learner, KRISP (Kate and Mooney, 2006)
clean_text: The remaining refined landmarks plans are then treated as supervised training data for a semantic-parser learner, KRISP (Kate and Mooney, 2006).

raw_text: To train a semantic parser using KRISP (Kate and Mooney, 2006), they had to supply aMRG, a context-free grammar, for their formal navigation plan language
clean_text: To train a semantic parser using KRISP (Kate and Mooney, 2006), they had to supply a MRG, a context-free grammar, for their formal navigation plan language.

citing_paper_authors: Rohit J., Kate | Raymond J., Mooney
raw_text: In this paper we present, to our knowledge, the first semi-supervised learning system for semantic parsing. We modify KRISP, a supervised learning system for semantic parsing presented in (Kate and Mooney, 2006), to make a semi-supervised system we call SEMISUP-KRISP
clean_text: We modify KRISP, a supervised learning system for semantic parsing presented in (Kate and Mooney, 2006), to make a semi-supervised system we call SEMISUP-KRISP.

citing_paper_authors: Rohit J., Kate | Raymond J., Mooney
raw_text: Learning SystemKRISP (Kernel-based Robust Interpretation for Semantic Parsing) (Kate and Mooney, 2006) is a supervised learning system for semantic parsing which 81takes NL sentences paired with their MRs as training data
clean_text: KRISP (Kernel-based Robust Interpretation for Semantic Parsing) (Kate and Mooney, 2006) is a supervised learning system for semantic parsing which takes NL sentences paired with their MRs as training data.

citing_paper_authors: Rohit J., Kate | Raymond J., Mooney
raw_text: Experimentally, KRISP compares favor ably to other existing semantic parsing systems and is particularly robust to noisy training data (Kate and Mooney, 2006)
clean_text: Experimentally, KRISP compares favorably to other existing semantic parsing systems and is particularly robust to noisy training data (Kate and Mooney, 2006).

raw_text: They solved the problem of aligning sentences and meanings by iteratively retraining an existing supervised semantic parser, WASP (Wong and Mooney, 2007b) or KRISP (Kate and Mooney, 2006), or an existing supervised natural-language generator, WASP? 1 (Wong and Mooney, 2007a)
